keyTakeAways: Thousands of residents in Catanduanes, Philippines, evacuated as Tropical Storm Fengshen approached, due to forecasted coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters high.
The storm brings heavy rainfall and a 'minimal to moderate risk' of coastal flooding, with gusts up to 80 km/h (50 mph) expected in the area.
Catanduanes, a poor island of 270,000 people, is one of the first landmasses hit by western Pacific cyclones, making it especially vulnerable.
The evacuation was part of a repeated drill, indicating preparedness efforts in place despite ongoing risks.
The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, often affecting impoverished, disaster-prone communities.
Scientists warn that increasing storm intensity is linked to human-driven climate change, suggesting long-term environmental threats.
The country is still recovering from previous disasters, including earthquakes and Typhoon Ragasa, which have already resulted in fatalities and mass evacuations.
Tropical Storm Fengshen adds to a pattern of extreme weather events, raising concerns about the cumulative impact on public safety and infrastructure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of residents in the Philippine island of Catanduanes evacuated their homes as Tropical Storm Fengshen approached, due to warnings of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters and wind gusts of up to 80 km/h. The evacuation, part of a recurring drill, underscores the island’s vulnerability as a frequent first hit for western Pacific cyclones. This event occurs amid a broader crisis in the Philippines, which has already experienced deadly earthquakes and Typhoon Ragasa, highlighting the country’s ongoing struggle with climate and seismic risks. Scientists have linked increasing storm intensity to human-driven climate change, suggesting long-term environmental and societal challenges.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
